content.text: The web is more than just text; it is a connectivity graph. Hyperlinks are the 'votes' that tell us which pages are authoritative and which are not.
content.hook: It's not just what you say; it's who cites you.

content.definition: A global ranking algorithm that measures the 'importance' of a page based on the number and quality of links pointing to it.
content.text: Logic: A page has high PageRank if it's linked to by many other high-PageRank pages. It models a 'Random Surfer' who eventually jumps to a new page.
content.hook: The mathematical foundation of Google's success.

content.definition: A query-dependent link analysis algorithm by Jon Kleinberg.
content.text: 1. Authorities: High-quality sources on a topic. 2. Hubs: Pages that point to many good authorities (e.g. curated lists).
content.hook: A good hub points to good authorities, and a good authority is pointed to by many good hubs.

content.description: How graph weights propagate through links.
Draw 4 websites (A, B, C, D). A links to B and C. B links to C. D links to A. Using the PageRank logic, which site is likely to be the most 'important'? What happens if C links back to D?
